statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Robert Dozier scored 15 points and Shawn Taggart and Tyreke Evans both added 12 as Memphis weathered a late rally to hold on for a 59-51 victory over Arkansas-Little Rock.
article.headline: Memphis holds off late rally to beat Arkansas-Little Rock
article.linkText: Memphis holds off Arkansas-Little Rock rally

inlines.body:
Fast Facts

• Memphis has won 66 straight home games vs unranked teams.

• The Tigers have won 20 of their last 23 December games and were 6-0 in the month last season.

• Arkansas-Little Rock fell to 0-3 all-time vs Memphis.

-- ESPN research

article.story: MEMPHIS, Tenn. -- A lackadaisical Memphis team almost went into cruise control too early. Robert Dozier scored 15 points and Shawn Taggart and Tyreke Evans both added 12 as the Tigers (No. 21 ESPN/USA Today, No. 23 AP) weathered a late rally to hold on for a 59-51 victory over Arkansas-Little Rock on Wednesday night. Dozier missed only one of his four shots from the field and was 9-of-12 from the line as the Tigers (6-2) rebounded from a 79-70 overtime loss at Georgetown on Saturday. But the effects of playing a close game on the road against a nationally ranked opponent could have produced a bit of a competitive hangover for the Tigers against the Trojans. "We just weren't prepared," Dozier said. "Guys came in during the warmups and the layup line, and you could kind of see it. Guys were just going through the motions or weren't going hard. We just all-around weren't prepared. We played sloppy." Memphis appeared to be in control, leading by 18 points with just under 10 minutes left. But a rally by the Trojans that included 3-pointers from Curtis Jackson, Matt Mouzy and Steven Moore cut the deficit to 51-45 with 2:26 left. UALR (7-3) got within five points on several occasions late, but Memphis was able to hold on down the stretch, despite not scoring from the field over the final 8:07. Moore led UALR with 16 points. "I thought we had a little bit more poise," Trojans coach Steve Shields said. "I was proud of our guys from a tenacity standpoint. We were down 18 at one point and continued to fight through a very talented and well-coached team." Memphis coach John Calipari wasn't talking about his team in terms of talent after trying several combinations. The usually talkative Calipari couldn't find a lot to say, other than mouthing a "Wow" for the escape and a rather somber "We'll get better" promise. In some cases, players aren't playing with confidence. "Guys are tentative," Calipari said. "They're not confident enough that they can finish the play. Why? Because they just missed three layups." Both teams shot just 33.3 percent from the field and Memphis was 3-of-20 from 3-point range. Evans was 2-of-9 from the field, while Taggart was 3-of-11. Meanwhile, UALR starting forwards Shane Edwards and Mike Smith were a combined 2-of-15 for the game. Still, Shields said his team stayed with their game plan and almost came back at the end. He noted that Memphis is much more successful when it forces turnovers. "I thought we did a good job of staying with our goal of keeping them off the offensive glass and closing gaps," Shields said. "You know there is little margin for error. "Early in the second half, we turned the ball over," he said. The early part of the first half was sloppy with both teams shooting poorly and having trouble holding onto the ball. Memphis shot 32 percent in the half, and that was better than the Trojans, who were 8-of-29 (28 percent). Memphis had six turnovers before the under-12 minute timeout. They finished with 12 in the game, while the Trojans committed 17. "If we weren't this good defensively," Calipari said. "This would be scary." UALR led 19-18 with 8:46 left in the half, but the Tigers closed the half on a 12-3 run. The Trojans made only one of their last nine shots in the half. Memphis turned up the defensive pressure in the second half and its lead reached 18. Mouzy's 3-pointer with 4:05 left capped a 10-0 run that got the Trojans within 50-42. But UALR could not get the deficit under five the rest of the way. Evans said he didn't get nervous as the Trojans cut into the lead. "We knew we were supposed to win that game," the freshman said. The Memphis players realize they don't have time to adjust or rebuild that confidence. They face No. 11 Syracuse on Saturday. "We definitely can't come out and play like this," Dozier said, "or we'll be behind 20 at home. They are going to come in here swinging."
